subject: Re: Portable Ghost Box System video
author: LC Duplatt
full_text:
Hey, no, thank you for sharing, Mike.  I went out and bought the 
microphone you use, and what a difference it should make.  It powers 
up with a AAA, so it probably ups the amps(?) so I can get more out 
of it than the lapel amped mic.  I am going to run experiments 
tonight and will update.

The echo chamber as Frank used might slow the mix down a bit and make 
it better to discern - so I want to test this, too.

LC


--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "M.A. Coletta (Mike)" 
<michaelcoletta@...> wrote:
>
> Hi LC,
> 
> Yes, the "click" can be cut down a bit by using a chamber.  It's 
> a "phase" thing.  When the "click" (or any sound wave) is reached 
at 
> the input mic at 180 degrees out of phase with the original I 
> understand there is a cancel effect.  That works with any sound 
wave I 
> think, so you're bound to have some "clicks" and their 180 out of 
phase 
> wave reaching the mic nearly at the same time, cancelling somewhat.
> There is so much bouncing going on in there I would love to see 
what 
> the entire pattern looks lke on a scope.  There must be alot of 
phase 
> shifting going on.
> 
> I tried my prototype with and without the chamber yesterday.  I 
found a 
> BIG different, and I'm sticking with the chamber effect.  For one 
> thing, it increased the amplification at least three-fold when I 
used 
> the chamber, not to mention all the mixing and phasing.
> 
> I hope to play some of my box audio files tonight on my internet 
radio 
> show. Both from my chamber system and from the three 12-469/mixer 
> system.
> 
> Hey, LC... keep up the good work, and thanks for sharing!
> 
> - Mike
